moves.1. d4: I think 1. d4 is very common. Usually I play 1 ... d5, but today I shall decide to do something different.
moves.1... Nf6: I'm not sure if this is the right knight, but I don't think I'll regret it too much.
moves.2. Nc3: White develops a knight. This protects the e4 square.
moves.2... d5: But I won't let white take care of the centre that easily.
moves.3... Nc6: I do the same. I am just trying to develop my pieces and take control of the centre, as everybody usually does.
moves.4. Bd2: I think this is an intresting move. It will be hard to develop the queen and connect the rooks, though.
moves.4... Bf5: First, develop my LSB, so I am then ready to play e6
moves.5. e3: This move lets white's LSB out but blocks the DSB. Anything better?
moves.5... e6 6. Bb5: Pinning my knight and getting ready to castle.
moves.6... Bd6: Attacking the defend h-pawn which might be a bit vulnerable after white castles.
moves.7. O-O: Gets the king into saftey, or does it?
moves.7... O-O 8. Re1: Nice move. But what's wrong with simply taking the c6 knight?
moves.8... Qd7: Develops my queen, protects the c6 knight and connects the rooks. 3 in 1!
moves.9. Qe2: White now connects his rooks. But I think his position is a bit squashed.
moves.10. Rad1: Good move. But the h2 pawn is left undefended.
moves.11. Bxc6: Which one is better, Bishop or Knight (in this position)?
moves.11... Qxc6 12. b4: White is trying to chase my Queen away.
moves.13. Ne5: A fine outpost for the knight, attacking my queen as well.

gameName: Which one is better, Bishop or Knight?
